The Maclaurin series for a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="the sum, from n equals 1, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator n times x to the n power, and denominator 2 times n squared, plus 1, end fraction"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo>∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and converges to <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="the absolute of value of x, end absolute value, is less than R"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="R"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the radius of convergence of the Maclaurin series. (a) Use the ratio test to find <math alttext="R"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
